cluster_relations.rel_desc: Waving hello is given as an example of a gesture.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Links a specific example or instance to the more general class or category it belongs to.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: A thumbs up is presented as an example of a gesture.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: A furrowed brow is presented as a kind of facial expression.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Links a specific example or instance to the more general class or category it belongs to.
remarks: Partly supported by entity description; treated as facial expression instance.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Eye contact is given as an example of body language in the discussion of its role in nonverbal communication.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Links a general category or behavior type to a specific instance that exemplifies that category.
remarks: Relation direction chosen as body language including eye contact as an example behavior.
Relation direction chosen as body language including eye contact as an example behavior.
Relation direction chosen as body language including eye contact as an example behavior.

args.justification: All four relations express membership of a specific behavior or gesture in a more general category (either as instance_of or its inverse has_example_instance). Using a more precise class label 'class_membership_relation' is clearer and less redundant than the generic 'categorization_relation' under rel_cls_group 'IDENTITY', while preserving the existing canonical_rel_name values.

executed_decisions.justification: All four relations express membership of a specific behavior or gesture in a more general category (either as instance_of or its inverse has_example_instance). Using a more precise class label 'class_membership_relation' is clearer and less redundant than the generic 'categorization_relation' under rel_cls_group 'IDENTITY', while preserving the existing canonical_rel_name values.
